messageBody:
On 4/3/07, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> On 4/3/07, Bradley, Todd <todd.bradley@...> wrote:
>
> > > What is the distinction between setup() and the constructor?
> >
> > I'm not sure if this is test runner specific behavior, but in my
> > experience the constructors are all called at the same time, before any
> > tests are run. And then setUp() is run immediately before each test
> > method is executed. That's with JUnit 3.8. I can't speak for version
> 4
> > as we haven't switched yet.
>
> Yes, but this doesn't answer Adrian's original question... (which I've
> always found hard to answer as well).


People who have been on the list a while have seen some good answers to that
question, but I'm happy to take another swipe at it. JUnit is built on the
assumption that your tests are cheap to initialize and run.

1) If your tests are cheap to initialize and run, then running each test
method on a distinct instance of a class gives the added benefit of ensuring
that tests are independent. I have several times had functional tests pass
when they should have failed, because I've forgotten to delete a file
created in one test before another test runs. I'm glad that JUnit doesn't
add in the potential confusion of state changed in one test affecting the
next test.

2a) If your tests are not cheap to initialize and run and you're calling
them unit tests, it's worth taking a look at whether there's a way to test
what the unit under test does without expensive persistent state. Often,
this thinking results in valuable design insights.

2b) If your tests are not cheap to initialize and run because they're
actually integration tests, acceptance tests, or end-to-end system tests,
then you might want state to persist, trading off safety for performance.
In JUnit 3.8, you can use TestSetup for this state, and in JUnit 4, you can
use @BeforeClass with statics, or you can search Google for "JUnit
OneInstance.class", which will give you a solution allowing you to only
instantiate your test class once.

Then again, I am in the camp of people who think that maintaining
> immutable state in tests is not only harmless, it's actually very
> useful. Which is why TestNG will not reinstantiate your test classes
> like JUnit does.


If I couldn't get my design decoupled enough to run my unit tests without
expensive state, I might also trade off safety for performance the way
TestNG does. With a reasonable object-oriented language, it seems that
never happens for me.

David Saff
